Inlined as DEFAULT_PRECISION.

keep this line directly below this elaborate comment adorning it

"Simplify HiveType.getTypeSignature with factory methods" also looks good % one comment.
You can split it out together with "Use the passed type to serialize in SerDeUtils"
Streams.zip does not necessarily improve readability, because i need to think what's the behavior when zipped streams have different lengths. I'd suggest dropping this change.

In this case, the lines above guarantee that the streams are the same size (because the two lists represents pairs of values). (This might be clearer with the comments above moved to the next line.)
(I actually find the indexed for-loop slightly less readable, because there's a moment of confusion before I parse why it's indexed instead of a for-each loop.)
This is now part of #6175, and I've copied over the comments.
the name of the class is "translator", so "translate" is not a bad name, is it?
I renamed that because I added other translation methods to the class.
Annotate the method @Nullable
you can replace the Map with an ordinary switch (keep it simple), which will allow you to add default case throwing cleanly in case of a new, unsupported HiveTimestampPrecision.

nodes.bodyText:
Hm. Maybe I should separate the common prefix and the write value?
No, that stops being easy to read, which defeats the point of the factory.
Then the current cases would look like the first line, and a case with rounding might look like the second:
timestampAndPrecision(NANOS, "2020-01-02 12:34:56.", "111111999", "111", "111112", "111111999"),
timestampAndPrecision(MICROS, "2020-01-02 12:34:", "39.999991999", "40.000", "39.999992", "39.999991999"),

I think I'll remove the string processing from the factory, but leave the separate arguments. This is much more useful than the current factory, and it's easier to see how the values relate than the original version where the values weren't lined up.
timestampAndPrecision(writeValue, writePrecision, milliReadValue, microReadValue, nanoReadValue);
// (First two arguments switched to keep the write value separate from the read value.)

timestampAndPrecision(
    "2020-01-02 12:34:56.111111999",
    NANOSECONDS,
    "2020-01-02 12:34:56.111",
    "2020-01-02 12:34:56.111112",
    "2020-01-02 12:34:56.111111999"),

timestampAndPrecision(
    "2020-01-02 12:23:39.111111999",
    NANOSECONDS,
    "2020-01-02 12:34:40.000",
    "2020-01-02 12:34:39.111112",
    "2020-01-02 12:34:39.111111999")

nodes.bodyText: My intellij automatically reformats this line into multiline form.

instead of passing "unchecked" DEFAULT_PRECISION, we should pass Optional<HiveTimestampPrecision>

there are places where hive.timestamp-precision doesn't matter --  a bunch of places dealing with bucketing columns, and timestamp cannot be bucketed on in Presto

it will be hard to find motivation to fix those cases, we will be tempted to use the now-deprecated methods


passing Optional.empty will allow us to signal "timestamp precision cannot matter here"; and will also allow us to validate this in fromPrimitiveType(PrimitiveTypeInfo typeInfo, below

Probably the Optional-taking method should be a public overload, so that we can call it directly in those places where we deal with bucketing columns. Currently we call the deprecated overload there, which looks not good, if we don't have plans to "fix" it.

I think renaming the method to something like getTypeWithUnknownTimePrecision might be a better idea if we don't plan to fix it, because it makes the meaning more clear.
If TypeManager were local to Hive, it would be a better idea to include the timestamp precision there, which could eliminate all but one use of getTypeSignature().

I think renaming the method to something like getTypeWithUnknownTimePrecision might be a better idea if we don't plan to fix it, because it makes the meaning more clear.

Sounds good!
(nit: TimePrecision -> TimestampPrecision)
let's address this as a followup
epochSecond
nanosOfSecond

rounding here may move you to next second (ie may return NANOS_PER_SECOND)
this needs to be handled here before invoking the DecodedTimestamp ctor
I've put it here, though that check should probably also be in the PrestoTimestampEncoders, or maybe DecodedTimestamp should have a separate constructor for that.
I don't understand this comment
I'll just remove it, it's misleading anyway.

I like including \n because IntelliJ highlights it, so it makes it more obvious when I'm missing whitespace; it's annoying when a test fails because I accidentally wrote "SELECTid,valueFROM sometable (and the failure messages aren't usually super helpful). (IntelliJ also includes the newlines if you use "edit SQL fragment" and use multiple lines.)
But as with the commas, it doesn't match the style elsewhere in the file, so I'll just indent everything with spaces instead (though at least one other test (TestHiveIntegrationSmokeTest) does use newlines in its SQL).

nodes.bodyText:
The original issue was that Hive tries to check permissions on the internal dummy table when you use a bare SELECT, and fails. I'm not actually sure if it was related to some types of authentication or if it shows up with any authentication at all.
(It looks like bug slipped through the gaps in Hive's development process. The ticket for this bug in version 1.1 was closed because it was resolved in another ticket, but that one doesn't list 1.1.)
(I'll just remove that line of the comment; it doesn't really matter.)

nodes.bodyText:
Let's not implicate views here. Let's just have single-row table.
I see you're concerned someone will add a second row to the table and thus it won't be single-row table anymore, but that would be rogue and tests would fail telling us about that. thus i wouldn't be concerned about that.
Already done. I just re-create the table each time.

The JDBC representation may or may not play tricks on us.
Would be nice to also (first) validate the typeof(the_array) and CAST(the_array AS varchar).
See also #6297. I use this technique in some other upcoming (unrelated) PR as well.

SET SESSION hive.timestamp_precision = 'NANOSECONDS';

+            throws SQLException
+    {
+        setAdminRole(onPresto().getConnection());

+
+        onPresto().executeQuery(format(

+                        + ",arr ARRAY(TIMESTAMP)\n"

+                        + ",nested ARRAY(MAP(TIMESTAMP, ROW(col ARRAY(TIMESTAMP))))\n"
+                        + ") WITH (%s)",
+                tableName,
+                format.getStoragePropertiesAsSql()));
+
+        // Insert in a loop because inserting with UNION ALL sometimes makes values invisible to Presto
+        for (TimestampAndPrecision entry : TIMESTAMPS_FROM_HIVE) {
+            onHive().executeQuery(format(
+                    "INSERT INTO %1$s\n"
+                            // insert with SELECT because hive bans array/map/struct functions in VALUES

Rename two methods in TestHiveStorageFormats

setupTimestampData to setupTimestampTable

The getPrecision could return the precision and let the (only) caller apply name() on their own.

and then

            _col0
-----------------------------

nodes.bodyText:
I find that having the fully-expanded test cases makes them harder to keep track of because there are so many covering similar cases.
But we probably don't need all of the test cases duplicated pre/post-epoch, so I'll remove the post-epoch duplication and add fewer, more explicit tests instead.

nodes.bodyText: public static Type fromPrimitiveType(PrimitiveTypeInfo typeInfo) should be deprecated now, right?

This is probably a change in behavior, but probably a correct one.
The old code
((TimestampWritable) object).getTimestamp().getTime() * MICROSECONDS_PER_MILLISECOND

inspector.getPrimitiveJavaObject(object).toEpochMilli() * MICROSECONDS_PER_MILLISECOND;

was probably truncating.
Am i correct?
Does it apply to timestamp outside of structural types as well?
Do we have a test for this?

Yes, the original version did truncate.

Does it apply to timestamp outside of structural types as well?

No; the only public API in SerdeUtils is getBlockObject1, which is only used in GenericHiveRecordCursor.parseObjectColumn, and only when type.getJavaType() == Block.class.

Do we have a test for this?

We did not previously have a  test for this (the only tests I can find I in five minutes for arrays in Hive is in TestHiveIntegrationSmokeTest). The tests added in this PR do cover it, though (because they test all available precisions).
We should probably have a class like TestHiveTypes. Should I open an issue for that?

1 serializeObject is also public, but it looks like it might be missing @VisibleForTesting. It is only used in SerDeUtils and tests, and its overload is @VisibleForTesting.
move the TIMESTAMP case back here, after DATE case.

How much time does the test take?
How many times do we run the test on CI?
storage formats are run in multiple configurations -- for good reason. Since HDFS access patterns vary between formats, we run these tests for all supported HDFS authentication/impersonation configurations. This one, however, doesn't need to be run for all of them. Thus --and especially if it takes significant amount of time -- we should change its group definiion. Perhaps, it would be enough to a) remove storage_format group and b) add a comment why the test is not in that group.
(this applies to existing test for nonstructural timestamp as well)
This test doesn't always have the same behavior for different storage formats because of time zone storage differences.
Can you do this with VALUES?

nodes.bodyText:
No, because Hive doesn't allow functions like array and named_struct in VALUES.


Hive does not support literals for complex types (array, map, struct, union), so it is not possible to use them in INSERT INTO...VALUES clauses. This means that the user cannot insert data into a complex datatype column using the INSERT INTO...VALUES clause.
